newsitem.title: UK: INTERVIEW - SmithKline sees lower debt levels.
newsitem.headline: INTERVIEW - SmithKline sees lower debt levels.

text.p: Anglo-American drugs firm SmithKline Beechman said it plans to cut its debt levels in coming years, but it said the drive would not prevent it from making an acquisition if a good opportunity comes along.

"We can reduce capital expenditure and we can improve our free cash flow and thereby will be able to reduce our debt levels," chief executive Jan Leschly told Reuters. "On the other hand we are not too concerned (about the debt level)."
SmithKline is striving to bring its gearing down to levels of around 50 percent after big investments in recent years pushed it up to 79 percent now.
"Obviously we would like to be below 100 (percent), but if a the right opportunity (to make an acquisition) comes up we will look at it," Leschly said.
"We always look for new opportunities for new products," he said, while adding: "We are, however, in the fortunate situation that we don't need to do anything."

But unlike rival Glaxo Wellcome, Leschly said he saw the current wave of mergers and acquisitions in the drug industry continuing unabatedly. "The market is very competitive. The changes in healthcare reforms...mean many companies will have to look at opportunities on how to save costs," he said.
SmithKline earlier reported a 20 percent rise in third quarter pre-tax profit to 374 million stg, coming in at the higher end of analysts' forecasts.
"We have a great success in our new product sales," Leschly said, specifically pointing to the "outstanding performance" of SmithKline's anti-depressant drug Seroxat/Paxil.
The product saw worldwide sales rise by 54 percent to 189 million stg.
Antibiotic Augmentin, one of SmithKline's biggest-selling drugs, posted a sales increase of nine percent to 290 million stg, while raising its market share in Europe and in the U.S.
Overall group sales grew 15 percent to 2.0 billion stg, led by an 80 percent volume rise in prescription drugs and a strong U.S. market.
"This quarter was really extraordinary in terms of sales growth," Leschly said.
